item.title: US wins UBS accounts deal
item.description: The US yesterday blasted a huge hole in Switzerland’s famed hallowed bank secrecy as Bern agreed to reveal the names of 4,450 wealthy rich Americans holding offshore accounts at UBS, the country’s biggest bank

item.title: Oil price rebound boosts Wall Street
item.description: A rebound in the price of oil boosted energy stocks and helped US equities reverse the morning’s losses

item.title: Jump in US office prices raises hopes
item.description: The price of offices in the US rose in the second quarter for the first time since 2007, offering a glimmer of hope for the stricken commercial property market, according to a report from Moody’s, the ratings agency

item.title: Taliban target Afghan polling stations
item.description: Officials and civilians have received warnings that militants will target voters in addition to military and government institutions.

item.title: Deere quarterly earnings beat expectations
item.description: John Deere, the world’s biggest maker of agricultural equipment, indicated that it did not expect to make a profit in the remainder of its fiscal yearwould struggle to make a profit in its current fiscal quarter, as it warned it faced “persistent global economic pressure”

item.title: ECB urges further stimulus measures
item.description: Emergency growth-stimulating policies are still needed to support Europe’s fragile economic recovery, Axel Weber, Germany’s Bundesbank president, has warned

item.title: FSA spells out rules for activist investors
item.description: The FSA has changed its rules to allow investors to work together to oust chief executives or press for changes to strategy without falling foul of EU or UK regulations

item.title: More than 95 dead in Baghdad attacks
item.description: Baghdad suffered a string of attacks that left more than 95 people dead in the latest sign that violence in Iraq has intensified in the wake of a handover from US troops to Iraqi security forces.

item.title: Recession easing among wealthier nations
item.description: An OECD analysis of the GDP of its largest members shows an average 0.1 per cent contraction in the second quarter of 2009, following 2.5 per cent in the first quarter, with the UK significantly weaker than its peers

item.title: HP profit plunge dashes tech recovery hopes
item.description: An anticipated expected recovery in technology markets that could add to early indications that the world is heading out of recession has yet to take hold, according to figures from Hewlett-Packard
